"I am proud to work here because of the great things we are doing and the progress we are making," writes Assistant Principal Victor Rodriguez. "Our school has just completed it second year and has already gone through several stages of development. Our staff is continuing to develop programs like advisories, electives and field study which offer students a more hands-on, one to one method of education rather than antiquated strategies which have been proven not to work. Our school is pioneering the "Opportunity Center" which is the name we have created to replace the school's SAVE room (schools against violence in education). We changed the name to take the negative connotation away from the room because our students are not violent and don't need to be saved. What they do need is an opportunity to become better. We have come a long way in just ten months and have recently added a dean and guidance counselor to further address social needs and ease the transition between elementary and high school. Our goal for this third year should be for all members of this learning community to work together in solving problems and not merely point them out. A parent wrote that we must realize that we make the difference in what our schools become and what we want for our children. I am proud to work with Ms. Becker, who realized something special about each of us that she hired and provided us a forum to speak freely and collaborate. I applaud the effort of our staff and parents and only hope that we can continue to work together in making Bronx Green a place that prepares our students academically, socially and emotionally."

"Bronx Green Middle School believes in its mission of empowering students academically, socially, and emotionally to make wise choices," writes a teacher. "Naturally, with a lofty mission like this, there is much room for great successes as well as challenges. Principal Emily Becker knows that children are not merely empty vessels needing to be filled with knowledge, and challenges teachers and students to create their own unique path for learning and discovery. Since many teachers and students are accustomed to being told what to do and how/when to do it, they can find it challenging to adapt to Principal Becker's more creative and progressive approach. Fortunately, Ms. Becker does not waiver in her dedication to the mission nor in her love for the children, and she continually provides both teachers and students with opportunities to create, lead, and maintain new possibilities. This is evident in the Student Internship Program, the Garden Design Exposition, the 100% attendance Broadway show trip, the Advisory program, the Community of Unity/ Culture Club teacher group, the Literacy through Photography Program, and the plethora of academically based field trips taken to a wide range of places all over the city and out to Pennsylvania. Principal Becker either piloted or encouraged each of these programs with unwavering support. Staff does not yell, but speak with confidence, authority, and inspiration. Teachers respect students, and expect to get the same in return. Teachers lead advisory classes during which students get an opportunity to bond with peers in a small group and share concerns and successes. The advisors play a vital role in teaching students to be responsible, productive members of the larger community at Bronx Green and offer students an open ear and gentle guidance. By communicating in such a manner and offering such support, teachers encourage students to conduct themselves responsibly and respectfully, and while it is easy to focus on the few who do not, the majority of our students deserve to be celebrated for being positive members of a growing green community."
